ygData.subject: New Paper: Innovation Engines -
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello all, I am pleased to announce a new paper written by Anh Nguyen, Jason Yosinski, and myself. It attempts to algorithmically recreate the explosion of

Date: Sun, 24 May 2015 10:26:24 -0600
Message-Id: <60EB3471-23C6-45D5-BCF9-9F3F1BCAA1AB@...>

 Jason Yosinski <jason@...>

Subject: New Paper: Innovation Engines -
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=nnipHRs94V8rwjW3rJ4rzIwK_Qcgpl7msXwOXbHRf59AJJhHuQG4
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune
From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>


--Apple-Mail=_C5BF18FC-C1C2-49FC-82E4-329DA13C2683
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=utf-8

Hello all,

I am pleased to announce a new paper written by Anh Nguyen, Jas=
on Yosinski, and myself. It attempts to algorithmically recreate the explos=
ion of creative diversity that occurred on Picbreeder and EndlessForms, wit=
h the ultimate aim of helping us move towards open-ended evolution (i.e. ev=
olutionary processes that endlessly innovate to produce a diversity of high=
-quality solutions). A key component is using Deep Learning to evaluate nov=
elty in a meaningful, low-dimensional space, because novelty search and oth=
er behavioral-diversity promoting techniques cannot work in high-dimensiona=
l spaces.
Nguyen A, Yosinski J, Clune J (2015) Innovation Engines: Automate=
d Creativity and Improved Stochastic Optimization via Deep Learning. <http:=
//www.evolvingai.org/InnovationEngine>Proceedings of the Genetic and Evolut=
ionary Computation Conference. (pdf <http://www.evolvingai.org/files/Innova=
tionEngine_gecco15.pdf>)
If you do not have time to read the paper, you may=
 enjoy browsing the figures to see all the amazing CPPN pictures that were =
evolved without a human in the loop. We have an even larger selection here:=
 http://www.evolvingai.org/innovationEngine <http://www.evolvingai.org/inno=
vationEngine>

We think it is particularly interesting that we can evolve t=
hese images without a crowd of humans given the fascinating paper by Woolle=
y and Stanley that argues that doing so is not possible if you specifically=
 try to evolve any individual type of picture. While our results and theirs=
 seem contradictory, we find them compatible because we think the =E2=80=9C=
Innovation Engine=E2=80=9D described in our paper captures what made the cr=
owd of humans so effective: (1) having a vast number of objectives simultan=
eously, (2) measuring performance and diversity in an abstract, high-level,=
 low-dimensional space, and (3) being willing to =E2=80=9Cgoal switch=E2=80=
=9D, i.e. head toward a new objective whenever near it. Innovation Engines,=
 like Picbreeder and EndlessForms, thus =E2=80=9Ccollect interesting steppi=
ng stones in every direction."

I want to highlight one result that I think=
 will be particularly interesting to this group: the paper suggests that ha=
ving a vast number of objectives can be as good as searching for novelty al=
one.  Actually, it can be better, because it includes a pressure for qualit=
y (e.g performance). In other words, perhaps the problem with objectives th=
at Ken, Joel, et al. have done a wonderful job elucidating is not really a =
problem with objectives, but a problem with having only one (or a few) obje=
ctives. If you think of Ken and Joel=E2=80=99s =E2=80=9Chard maze=E2=80=9D,=
 it=E2=80=99s clear that the one single objective poisons the search for th=
e goal. But imagine if there were 20 objectives in that maze (go to the top=
-right corner, go to the bottom-right corner, etc.). In that case it, is cl=
ear that you would get exploration and eventually find the goal. If perform=
ance is defined as speed to the objective, you may thus end up with a more =
efficient (high-performing) behavior that reaches the goal. So, maybe what =
makes natural evolution produce so much diversity is not a pressure for nov=
elty alone (even with a minimal criteria), but instead the existence of mil=
lions of niches, where there is still an arms race to be the best at each o=
f those objectives, but where the fact that there are so many, and thus the=
 possibility of goal switching, fuels the production of things that are bot=
h diverse and high-performing. Figure 9 in the paper shows that goal-switch=
ing is essential to reach complex objectives, precisely because the path to=
 any complex objective (as Ken and Joel et al have pointed out), is *not* t=
o increasingly resemble/perform well on that objective. Instead, the path c=
an be quite circuitous, but if you collect interesting stepping stones in a=
ny direction, you may eventually find yourself one step away from something=
 complex that you otherwise would never have found by trying to head straig=
ht for it. 

We are very excited about the ideas in this paper, and we woul=
d really enjoy hearing what you think about them! Please let us know if you=
 have any comments, questions, objections, etc. 

ABSTRACT The Achilles Hee=
l of stochastic optimization algorithms is getting trapped on local optima.=
 Novelty Search avoids this problem by encouraging a search in all interest=
ing directions. That occurs by replacing a performance objective with a rew=
ard for novel behaviors, as defined by a human-crafted, and often simple, b=
ehavioral distance function. While Novelty Search is a major conceptual bre=
akthrough and outperforms traditional stochastic optimization on certain pr=
oblems, it is not clear how to apply it to challenging, high-dimensional pr=
oblems where specifying a useful behavioral distance function is difficult.=
 For example, in the space of images, how do you encourage novelty to produ=
ce hawks and heroes instead of endless pixel static? Here we propose a new =
algorithm, the Innovation Engine, that builds on Novelty Search by replacin=
g the human-crafted behavioral distance with a Deep Neural Network (DNN) th=
at can recognize interesting differences between phenotypes. The key insigh=
t is that DNNs can recognize similarities and differences between phenotype=
s at an abstract level, wherein novelty means interesting novelty. For exam=
ple, a novelty pressure in image space does not explore in the low-level pi=
xel space, but instead creates a pressure to create new types of images (e.=
g. churches, mosques, obelisks, etc.). Here we describe the long-term visio=
n for the Innovation Engine algorithm, which involves many technical challe=
nges that remain to be solved. We then implement a simplified version of th=
e algorithm that enables us to explore some of the algorithm=E2=80=99s key =
motivations. Our initial results, in the domain of images, suggest that Inn=
ovation Engines could ultimately automate the production of endless streams=
 of interesting solutions in any domain: e.g. producing intelligent softwar=
e, robot controllers, optimized physical components, and art.


Best regard=
s,
Jeff Clune

Assistant Professor, Computer Science
Director, Evolving Art=
ificial Intelligence Lab <http://evolvingai.org/>
University of Wyoming
jef=
fclune@...
jeffclune.com


--Apple-Mail=_C5BF18FC-C1C2-49FC-82E4-329DA13C2683

llo all,</div><div class=3D""><br class=3D""></div><div class=3D"">I am ple=
ased to announce a new paper written by Anh Nguyen, Jason Yosinski, and mys=
elf. It attempts to algorithmically recreate the explosion of creative dive=
rsity that occurred on Picbreeder and EndlessForms, with the ultimate aim o=
f helping us move towards open-ended evolution (i.e. evolutionary processes=
 that endlessly innovate to produce a diversity of high-quality solutions).=
 A key component is using Deep Learning to evaluate novelty in a meaningful=
, low-dimensional space, because novelty search and other behavioral-divers=
ity promoting techniques cannot work in high-dimensional spaces.</div><div =

>Nguyen A, Yosinski J, Clune J</span> </span><span class=3D"views-fiel=
d views-field-field-year"><span class=3D"field-content">(2015)</span> =
</span><span class=3D"views-field views-field-title"><span class=3D"field-c=
ontent"><a href=3D"http://www.evolvingai.org/InnovationEngine" style=3D"tex=
t-decoration: none; color: rgb(48, 74, 167);" class=3D"">Innovation Engines=
: Automated Creativity and Improved Stochastic Optimization via Deep Learni=
ng.</a></span></span><span class=3D"views-field views-field-field-bib"><spa=
n class=3D"field-content">Proceedings of the Genetic and Evolutionary Compu=
tation Conference.</span> </span><span class=3D"views-field views-fiel=
d-field-pdf">(<a href=3D"http://www.evolvingai.org/files/InnovationEngine_g=
ecco15.pdf" target=3D"_blank" style=3D"text-decoration: none; color: rgb(48=
, 74, 167);" class=3D"">pdf</a>)</span></li></ul></div><div class=3D"">If y=
ou do not have time to read the paper, you may enjoy browsing the figures t=
o see all the amazing CPPN pictures that were evolved without a human in th=
e loop. We have an even larger selection here: <a href=3D"http://www.e=
volvingai.org/innovationEngine" class=3D"">http://www.evolvingai.org/innova=
tionEngine</a></div><div class=3D""><br class=3D""></div><div class=3D"">We=
 think it is particularly interesting that we can evolve these images witho=
ut a crowd of humans given the fascinating paper by Woolley and Stanley tha=
t argues that doing so is not possible if you specifically try to evolve an=
y individual type of picture. While our results and theirs seem contradicto=
ry, we find them compatible because we think the =E2=80=9CInnovation Engine=
=E2=80=9D described in our paper captures what made the crowd of humans so =
effective: (1) having a vast number of objectives simultaneously, (2) measu=
ring performance and diversity in an abstract, high-level, low-dimensional =
space, and (3) being willing to =E2=80=9Cgoal switch=E2=80=9D, i.e. head to=
ward a new objective whenever near it. Innovation Engines, like Picbreeder =
and EndlessForms, thus =E2=80=9Ccollect <i class=3D"">interesting</i> stepp=
ing stones in every direction."</div><div class=3D""><br class=3D""></div><=
div class=3D"">I want to highlight one result that I think will be particul=
arly interesting to this group: the paper suggests that having a vast numbe=
r of objectives can be as good as searching for novelty alone.  Actual=
ly, it can be better, because it includes a pressure for quality (e.g perfo=
rmance). In other words, perhaps the problem with objectives that Ken, Joel=
, et al. have done a wonderful job elucidating is not really a problem with=
 objectives, but a problem with having only one (or a few) objectives. If y=
ou think of Ken and Joel=E2=80=99s =E2=80=9Chard maze=E2=80=9D, it=E2=80=99=
s clear that the one single objective poisons the search for the goal. But =
imagine if there were 20 objectives in that maze (go to the top-right corne=
r, go to the bottom-right corner, etc.). In that case it, is clear that you=
 would get exploration and eventually find the goal. If performance is defi=
ned as speed to the objective, you may thus end up with a more efficient (h=
igh-performing) behavior that reaches the goal. So, maybe what makes natura=
l evolution produce so much diversity is not a pressure for novelty alone (=
even with a minimal criteria), but instead the existence of millions of nic=
hes, where there is still an arms race to be the best at each of those obje=
ctives, but where the fact that there are so many, and thus the possibility=
 of goal switching, fuels the production of things that are both diverse an=
d high-performing. Figure 9 in the paper shows that goal-switching is essen=
tial to reach complex objectives, precisely because the path to any complex=
 objective (as Ken and Joel et al have pointed out), is *not* to increasing=
ly resemble/perform well on that objective. Instead, the path can be quite =
circuitous, but if you collect interesting stepping stones in any direction=
, you may eventually find yourself one step away from something complex tha=
t you otherwise would never have found by trying to head straight for it.&n=
bsp;</div><div class=3D""><br class=3D""></div><div class=3D"">We are very =
excited about the ideas in this paper, and we would really enjoy hearing wh=
at you think about them! Please let us know if you have any comments, quest=
ions, objections, etc. </div><div class=3D""><br class=3D""></div><div=
 class=3D"">ABSTRACT The Achilles Heel of stochastic optimization algorithm=
s is getting trapped on local optima. Novelty Search avoids this problem by=
 encouraging a search in all interesting directions. That occurs by replaci=
ng a performance objective with a reward for novel behaviors, as defin=
ed by a human-crafted, and often simple, behavioral distance function. Whil=
e Novelty Search is a major conceptual breakthrough and outperforms traditi=
onal stochastic optimization on certain problems, it is not clear how to ap=
ply it to challenging, high-dimensional problems where specifying a us=
eful behavioral distance function is difficult. For example, in the space o=
f images, how do you encourage novelty to produce hawks and heroes instead =
of endless pixel static? Here we propose a new algorithm, the Innovation En=
gine, that builds on Novelty Search by replacing the human-crafted beh=
avioral distance with a Deep Neural Network (DNN) that can recognize intere=
sting differences between phenotypes. The key insight is that DNNs can reco=
gnize similarities and differences between phenotypes at an abstract level,=
 wherein novelty means interesting novelty. For example, a novelty pre=
ssure in image space does not explore in the low-level pixel space, but ins=
tead creates a pressure to create new types of images (e.g. churches, mosqu=
es, obelisks, etc.). Here we describe the long-term vision for the Innovati=
on Engine algorithm, which involves many technical challenges that rem=
ain to be solved. We then implement a simplified version of the algorithm t=
hat enables us to explore some of the algorithm=E2=80=99s key motivations. =
Our initial results, in the domain of images, suggest that Innovation Engin=
es could ultimately automate the production of endless streams of inte=
resting solutions in any domain: e.g. producing intelligent software, robot=
 controllers, optimized physical components, and art.</div><div class=3D"">=
